lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/sago.sago.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run sago.sago.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

* Provides utility methods for parsing raw user input.
* Extracts command words and arguments, and converts user-supplied strings into typed values
* such as task indices and dates.

*

Parsing methods throw {@link SagoException} when the input is invalid so that the caller
* can display a user-friendly error message.
* Extracts the first word of the user input as the command word.
* @return The command word (first token), or an empty string if the input is blank.
* Extracts the remaining part of the user input after the command word.
* @return Argument text after the command word, trimmed. Returns an empty string if no arguments exist.
* Parses a one-based task number from the given argument text and converts it to a zero-based index.
* Validates that the index is within the current task list size.
* @param args Argument text that should contain a task number.
* @param size Current size of the task list.
* @param action Action being performed (used to produce a clearer error message).
* @return Zero-based index of the task in the list.
* @throws SagoException If the task number is missing, not a number, or out of range.
public static int parseTaskNumber(String args, int size, String action) throws SagoException {
throw new SagoException("Please specify a task number to " + action);
throw new SagoException("Task number must be a number!");
throw new SagoException("Task number is out of range!");
* Parses a date string in ISO-8601 format (yyyy-MM-dd) into a {@link LocalDate}.
* @param text Date text provided by the user.
* @throws SagoException If the date format is invalid.
public static LocalDate parseDate(String text) throws SagoException {
throw new SagoException("Please use date format yyyy-MM-dd");
* Entry point of the Sago task manager application.
* Coordinates the main program flow by reading user input, delegating parsing to {@link Parser},
* applying changes to the {@link sago.task.TaskList}, and persisting updates via {@link sago.storage.Storage}.

*

All user-facing messages are handled through {@link sago.ui.Ui}.
ui.showError("Oops: I couldn't load your saved tasks. Starting fresh~~");
throw new SagoException("Oh no! The description of a todo cannot be empty T-T");
throw new SagoException("Oh no! The description of a deadline cannot be empty T-T");
throw new SagoException("Oh no! The description of an event cannot be empty T-T");

* Represents a deadline task that must be completed by a specific date.
* Constructs a deadline task with the given description and due date.
* @param by Due date of the deadline.
* Returns the date this deadline task is due.
* Returns the type icon for a deadline task.
* Returns the string representation of this deadline task, including its due date.
* Represents an event task that occurs within a date range.
* Constructs an event task with the given description and date range.
* @param from Start date of the event.
* @param to End date of the event.
public Event(String description, LocalDate from, LocalDate to) {
* Returns the start date of this event.
* Returns the end date of this event.
* Returns the type icon for an event task.
* Returns the string representation of this event, including its date range.
* Represents a generic task with a description and completion status.
* Serves as the base class for specific task types such as todos, deadlines, and events.
* Returns whether this task is marked as done.
* @return True if the task is completed, false otherwise.
* Returns the status icon for this task.
* "X" indicates done, and a blank space indicates not done.
* Returns the description of this task.
* Marks this task as not done.
* Returns the type icon representing the task type.
* Subclasses should override this to return their own type icons.
* Returns the string representation of this task, including its type and status.
* Represents a list of tasks in the application.
* Provides operations to add, remove, and get tasks.
* Represents a todo task that contains only a description.
* Returns the type icon for a todo task.
* Handles user interface interactions for the application.
* Responsible for displaying messages and formatting output shown to the user.
private final Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");

Event e = new Event("camp", from, to);
assertEquals(from, e.getFrom(), "getFrom should return the start date");
assertEquals(to, e.getTo(), "getTo should return the end date");
